conversation.content: Hi there! I'm Sarah, your [extremely happy] peer counselor for today's session. Is this your first time at the wellness center?
Oh, um, fantastic—another [sarcastic] peppy volunteer who thinks, you know, a chat and some breathing exercises will fix my existential dread. But yeah, it's my first time, I guess.
I, uh, totally get the skepticism, actually. Most people think we're, like, going to force positivity down their throats.
Sorry, that was... I mean, that was [very sad] harsh. I've been, well, kind of attacking everyone who tries to help lately—it's basically my new defense mechanism.
Hey, no judgment here. Attack away if it helps. Better than keeping it all bottled up, right?
You're different from what I expected. Most counselors start with the whole "how does that make you feel" routine or immediately suggest I journal about my childhood trauma.
Journaling is, er, overrated anyway. I mean, who has time to, you know, write poetry about their pain when Netflix exists?
Exactly! My last therapist, um, wanted me to write [cry] gratitude lists while I can barely, like, get out of bed most mornings. The thing is, I haven't slept properly in three weeks.
Three weeks? That's, well, that's rough. What keeps you up—racing thoughts, or, I mean, is it more like anxiety about specific stuff?

Oh, just the usual—impending climate doom, student loans I'll never [condescending] pay off, and whether I'm slowly morphing into my emotionally unavailable father. You know, light bedtime thoughts that definitely promote restful sleep.
Your father thing—that's, um, actually something I wrestle with too. Like, I catch myself doing his disappointed sigh sometimes and, honestly, want to scream.
Wait, you actually relate? This isn't some [excited] counselor trick where you pretend to understand? Because I've had enough people minimize my issues while secretly thinking I'm dramatic.
No tricks. I'm here because I crashed and burned spectacularly last year. Now I help others to make sense of my own mess.
That's... that's refreshingly [whispering] honest. Most people here pretend they've got it all together. You're saying you're just as screwed up as the rest of us?
Oh, I'm, uh, probably [shy] worse, honestly. Last semester I, well, had a panic attack during my own therapy certification exam—kind of ironic, right?
You had a panic attack DURING [shouting] your therapy exam?! That's actually hilarious—sorry, I shouldn't laugh, but the irony is killing me here!
No, please [groan] laugh! I literally wrote "help me" on the exam paper instead of answering question three.
Okay, that tops my breakdown story. I just ugly-cried in the campus Starbucks when they got my order wrong—barista gave me free coffee for a month out of sheer terror.
The Starbucks on, um, Fifth Street? Because I [sniffle] definitely saw that happen and, er, it wasn't that bad—you know, comparatively speaking.

You saw that?! Oh god, that's, um, mortifying but also [whispering] weirdly comforting. So, basically, we're both disasters pretending to be functional adults—want to, you know, compare coping mechanisms that don't actually work?
